Author: @ruolbu
Comment:
I love THAT Death Stranding is a thing. I love that a high profile name like Kojima made not just a hiking game, but also a hiking game that is so controversial that it sticks with people. I love that terrain navigation is a concept in people's minds now and that Strand Type Games ‚Äì even if nebulous and rare ‚Äì is a genre now.

I just regret that I don't enjoy Death Stranding a lot. Maybe I'm misunderstanding it. But to me, it's a hiking game. In a genuine and affectionate way. I want games that are about hiking, about being in nature, experiencing it as more than a scenery, instead as a playground, as obstacles, as challenges, as not just the space between endpoints, but the goal itself.

But DS kinda puts too much weight on the obstacle thing, making it a mere level, making it hostile and unappealing, making the tech-solution to avoid nature more appealing than engaging with it. So to me, Death Stranding is a prototype, one that opens potential, but its direction is not my thing.

Instead I quite like Ghost Recon Wildlands. Play solo, style your character somewhat civilian like, and just hike slowly through nature. I role play taking the easy path instead of the rocky one, because obviously these meachanics aren't in there. But you get SO much majestic and magic nature by just playing this game slowly. And after 1-2 hours of wandering though a valley, up a hill and along some train tracks, you get to do some fun sneaky-shooty stuff at your own leisure. Now that's my style.

Author: @Road_to_Dawn
Comment:
I have a different sort of relationship with Death Stranding than I have with probably any other game. I‚Äôve been playing it since launch and still haven‚Äôt beaten it, but I‚Äôm just really, REALLY taking my time with it. I‚Äôll play it for a few days, work on rebuilding some roads, construct gigantic zipline networks all over the map, get every node to 5 stars. And then I‚Äôll put it down for a few months, and then pick it back up and do the same some more.

Most games I play for the story or for the characters, and gameplay is secondary. But I almost don‚Äôt care about the story in Death Stranding. I pay attention to each cutscene and I enjoy them, but I also don‚Äôt focus on them and partially as a result of playing the same save file over 5 years, I actually don‚Äôt even remember most of the story.

I love this game for the hiking, for the building, for the deliveries, and for the experience of setting out on another journey. That‚Äôs my favorite thing about it: accepting a delivery, and then planning my trip. What do I bring with me? What do I leave behind? What route should I take? And then making that trek and experiencing the land itself.

I know Death Stranding 2 is coming, but I‚Äôve not watched any trailers or anything. I‚Äôve no idea what it‚Äôs going to be like, but I just hope it has more of what I love about the first game, and more ways to experience the journey. I think I‚Äôm near the end of the first game finally (I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs been 5 years!), and I‚Äôm looking forward to the sequel. Before I play Death Stranding 2 though, I‚Äôm considering going back after I‚Äôve finished this one to replay it from the beginning with the Director‚Äôs Cut this time. (I‚Äôm still playing this first time through vanilla.)

Author: @Marabcd315
Comment: To address one of your lingering criticisms, and this could very well be cope that I've decided a clearly bad aspect of a game I like is good actually, I really don't think the game would be as solid a product overall if the combat felt better. Similarly to something like Alan Wake (1 and 2) I think the clunkiness in its design goes a long way to both communicate that Sam is not a soldier, and to dissuade the player from wanting to engage in violence (it's annoying, it's time consuming, and even if you win it takes up a bunch of resources that you're not guaranteed to get back from their cache). Granted, this is undercut somewhat by way the forced combat sections of the narrative are structured, but it overall really works for me. Making the combat more fun or engaging in the sequel would make for a better game experience and a less interesting game, I feel the same about the jump between NieR Replicant and NieR Automata where even though Automata is by basically all measures a better crafted experience I keep coming back to Replicant and I really don't with Automata because Replicant's frustrating design works to supplement its narrative in a much more interesting way than anything Automata does with its gameplay, and I don't really want to see the same happen to Death Stranding

Author: @nocreditclear
Comment:
Perhaps I'm predisposed to this line of thinking since my tastes in games leans toward ones that require a lot of time investment (JRPGs, work simulator/"dad" games, MMOs etc.) but I think this obsession with "respecting the player's time" that has permeated the collective mindset of players has done long-lasting damage to how we engage with videogames.

It's completely understandable how we got to this point (there is Too Much Media and always the desire to see more of it), and it would be a lie to say that there aren't games that completely waste the player's time for no reason (live service engagement and retention mechanics being the obvious example), but we're planted solidly in an era where it is difficult to find spaces or voices online that are willing to stop treating media consumption like a grindset. Yes this RPG is long. You could play several indie games in this amount of time. But was the time it asked of you meaningless? Was fostering familiarity in you, and giving you time to exist in a space or with characters, truly worthless? Did it "not respect your time", or do you just value your own time so little that the only way it can be spent meaningfully is by minmaxing your media consumption?

Author: @VicViper1984
Comment:
I REALLY hate to be that guy, but the condition of the goods you're delivering is not dependent on the condition of the containers they're in. Container repair spray only fixes those containers and not the goods inside, meaning that if you went through all that effort to fix the containers before delivering them, you just wasted a whole lot of effort for nothing because the goods inside them were just fine already.

Goods don't get damaged by timefall itself unless their containers are completely destroyed or the container is thrown around, dropped, or otherwise handled in a way that will shake their contents around which is more likely the weaker the integrity of the container is.

Author: @IndustrialBonecraft
Comment:
I'm pretty sure that Death Stranding represents an increasingly emergent subgenre of game that I'm not sure how to categorise, but is effectively the equivalent of "literary" fiction. 
It's experimenting with a bunch of ideas in more 'meditative' ways than a typical thriller sci-fi/"speculative" fiction story would do if it just wanted to pull a by-the-numbers hero's journey. 
It is, from an experiential perspective, more challenging and difficult to (both literally and figuratively) navigate. 

And like literary fiction, it's hard to pull off, the audience is typically somewhat smaller, and generally older with a different set of experiences and perspectives on life than the audience that the more "standard" form of media is aiming at. And I wonder if that is part of why a lot of people are coming back to it and finding it more enjoyable this time.

Author: @mathieupr6391
Comment:
Oner of the most satisfying experience I've had in a game were managing to set-up a network of zipline from Mountain node city to the Lake one, while having a chunk in the middle of the mountains not connected to the Chiral network.

This implied managing to put those ziplines in the exact pixel it would actually work on, on some very steep mountain ridges, while managing to find the exact spot within the maximum distance that would somehow manage to be in reach of each other over the unconnected territory (there's like a 200-300 meter section at one point that you can go over). Took me a good two hours of mountaineering all over the place, trying not to lose my material to set-up this whole thing up, but man was it satisfying to finally be able to bridge that gap and make every single mountain delivery a breeze for the next few hours until I could connect that little section.

Whenever I think of Death Stranding, my mind instantly goes to Sam perched on top of a thin snowy ridge, trying to line up that damn zipline perfectly. It's like a core memory of the game for me

And as I'm watching the video, annother memory popped up. one of the first deliveries on the first map, tripping while crossing the river and watching my whole cargo slowly drift away from my as I frantically run to try and catch-up to it, but nothing to grab it anyway, until I stumbled accross another player's abandonned ladder washed-up on the shore, which allowed me to put a precarious bridge on the river to grab my floating stuff. 

And I'm sure I can recall a bunch of moments like that if I try. Been willing to revisit the game for a while as DS 2 approches. Maybe I will now.

Author: @OpoOnTheGo
Comment: I'm not going to lie... this is a fate I deserved. Upon it''s launch, i overshared my ire for it's basic concept. It's the antithesis to what i had come to know as gaming after all, i had a decent enough excuse. But in the years since, i've become much more of a casual gamer. I lack the time and patience to get good at things, so i play things that i'm familiar with or are simply easy... but this game simply flipped the script in ways i could never have predicted. A lot of the time, the journey is the adventure in the most organic way. Before you connect to the chiral network, there's no POIs, no paths, no blueprint... and when the story beats kick in with the soundtrack? It's almost haunting, but in a comforting way. And then the world springs to life after linking your cupid! It's strange to say i've made friends here? Strangers who'd started the game the same time as me, who I ended up making bridge contracts with. Now every time i see their structures in my world, it's a friendly reminder to keep on keeping on. Every meticulously placed vehicle, generator, timefall shelter... zipline routes that present themselves as i invest my time in the chiral network. From the dropped cargo to paths tread, and even signs... this is the most positive social experience gaming has given me in a long while, and it's without even meeting your peers "face to face." I joked about Kojima calling this game the first of it's kind when it dropped, but the joke was on me. I don't even know if death stranding 2 will provide us a similar experience lol. Never has a game focused more on being a rope, the stick always proves more popular. This was and is something special, and i'm so glad i was hilariously wrong about it! Just got BB back... in going back to reguild the roads for the homies lol

Author: @AnikethBandi
Comment:
From hearing your critisims and how people reacted. For some of them I see what you mean, especially with the Chiral Artist cutscene. Like yeah the commenters are right, there's some sorta meaning behind it, but its still acted out like shit. 

But on the other hand your criticism about not seeing any humans, I feel that's just a agree to disagree scenario. Not saying its a bad criticism, but at the same time your opinion on that matter just comes down to the preference of how you want your story told right? I can see why you personally might want to see more humans, because it adds more weight to the actions of connecting America and connecting people. You hardly ever get to see the actual impact of your work on the average person besides the people at each center or the preppers. 

But at the same time somebody who says that the reason its like that is to create a feeling of loneliness has a valid point as well. One of the most beautiful thing about Death Stranding is the ambience. How you just traverse the world and its just you, your enemies, and the very few friends you truly have by your side. Everyone is at odds, even Sam and Bridges, which is arguably one of the biggest reasons you don't see many people. Sam doesn't want to see too many people, he's a lonely guy by nature. And he is slowly but surely building a proper connection with the few people who he is willing to interact with.

Now me saying all of this doesn't automatically make me right or your criticism wrong. Its simply a difference in preference of how we want the game world to be like. So I don't know if that itself is a great example of people simply refusing to admit there are flaws in the game because it is extremely subjective and your opinion will always be reflective on the type of stories you like. So there should be people like you saying you don't like it but ALSO people saying they like it. Both sides should be allowed to express their opinion on this matter.

Author: @andresilvasophisma
Comment:
A bit of context about the acting.
Some of the characters are portrayed by people that Kojima invited to do cameos.
That particular girl is Mala Morgan, a model.
A few other cameos are:
Video Game Awards host Geoff Keighley
Japanese Musician Daichi Miura
Japanese horror artist and writer, Junji Ito.
Film Director Jordan Vogt-Roberts.
Shaun of Dead and Baby Driver director Edgar Wright. 
Former Famitsu chief editor Hirokazu Hamamura.
Canadian born ACRONYM designer, Errolson Hugh.
Conan O‚ÄôBrien.
Remedy's Sam Lake.
Dead Snow and Hansel & Gretel: Witch Hunters director, Phillip North.
Japanese novelist Manabu Makime.  

As you can see none of them are actually actors by trade, so you can understand why the acting seems off.

Author: @trop3848
Comment:
The custcene that starts around 8:11 is a second language performance, so it's not quite at the level of some of the others. That said, it isn't "nonsense," and if you listen to what she's actually saying, the semantic content of her words makes pretty much perfect sense in the context of the series of missions she's in. Critique the performance all you want, but not "knowing what she's talking about" (her husband, the day they got separated, their wider relationship and her desire to try again) is the result of some problem on your end. All of the missions you do for this lady and her husband prior to this point set up this hopeful soliloquy, and the lore about how they got separated by terrorists so I'm really struggling to understand how you got lost here.

I'm not going to try and tell you this cutscene isn't kind of weak, or that the acting cant come off a little wonky to certain ears, but I really am slightly baffled by that particular point of critique.

Author: @venn7eance925
Comment:
I am fairly confident that despite attaching two batteries to your backpack, the game doesn't register the second one and therefore doesn't stack power. You'd be better off scrapping one of the batteries and depending on your choice of activities when playing recongifure your attachments accordingly. Myself, I go for a lvl4 battery pack, utility pouch (allows 8 Blood packs to be stored, which is useful if you like farming the "boss" BTs) and 3 large grenade pouches (9 grenade capacity total, so I take 8 lvl2 Hematic grenades and 1 Remote Stun grenade for taking out MULE/Terrorist trucks). 

Something else I saw in your "Directors Cut is a waste..." video was you were using Hematic rounds when shooting the Terrorists, which is a waste of blood as it has no effect on human enemies. Save blood and use standard ammo in your weapons.

Author: @Dump_Truck_Pud
Comment:
With the complaint around 10:50 for the story not making sense, I have to disagree. It's basically a scifi, so you have to do a lot of listening, reading, and paying attention to the world around.

In my first playthrough, I ignored the whole ha and ka thing, and I felt the same, but reading through the interview section really made everything make sense: Ha (body) and Ka (mind) are separated upon death, Ka tries to go back to body but can't. People start experimenting with brain-dead pregnant women (lost ka), but the baby is still alive and gets an unnatural birth (c-section). Since the bodies are connected with an alive one and a brain-dead one, the world of the living and dead sort of intersect, and the Ka of the brain-dead mother comes to reunite with the body. This creates a BT. Scientists do this across the country, and voidouts occur, which
are the result of anti-matter (BTs) and matter (living) coming into contact. Happened enough where a tear between the world of the living and the in between that the Ka goes through to get to the land of the dead occurs. The intersection is called the Beach and the tear is called the Death Stranding.

I think this happens if u dont pay attention to the emails and ‚Äúinterviews‚Äù Sam receives and unlocks throughout the game. Though the finale loooong cutscene at the end I feel like also just makes everything clear, but I guess the issue could be that if you dont read the stuff in the game, the game‚Äôs story will definitely feel like unsolved puzzle pieces until the end. 

The main point of the game‚Äôs storytelling I think relies on if the player was able to have emotional connection with BB and Clifford. Author: @tenorenstrom
Comment:
Was afraid I wouldn‚Äôt like DS so I never picked it up. Finally changed my mind (free on ps plus). 

The first few hours were horrendous. I‚Äôm a sucker for exposition in lieu of story so that kept me going. But I also read on Reddit people saying that if it doesn‚Äôt click with you once your like get your BB it‚Äôll never click. It didn‚Äôt click with me until that first Higgs encounter like 4h or so hours in. 

But once it clicked it REALLLY clicked. I‚Äôve come to love this game! There are tons of small annoyances and the only boarding process is terribly borked likely scaring off quite a few people.

But once DS hits its stride I couldn‚Äôt put it down. I really feel Kojima has indeed created a new genre. I for one would love for someone to create a sandbox mmorpg as a Strands-like. (combat needs to be better than in DS though)

Author: @slovnicurling9808
Comment:
10:48 Sorry to be that guy but the story is comprehensible if you pay attention what the characters say. But the fact you say "death stranding came in somehow" tells me you didn't even care about the story. Because if you did you would be glued to the screen when you go to Amelie's beach at the end and listened carefuly when she explains everything. I'm not saying the story is easily fully comprehensible the first time because it can be hours between important cutscenes so you naturally forget some details but if you played the game multiple times as you claiming you should have no problem unederstaning who is the bb in the "elevator flashback" or what started the Death stranding. Spoiler alert: these two things are related (or should I say connected) to each other. Sorry but that's objectively bad take from your side. Just say you didn't understand it instead that it's nonsensical because it just isn't.
EDIT: Also no octopuses in the game sorry. Starting to realize I might not even finish your video. You have no idea what is going on in the game, you just liked the delivery part. Nothing wrong with that but your opinions and arguments are almost completely irrelevant for people who did get the story. Also contrary to you I think that's the strongest part of the game. I feel like Kojima main goal was to tell the story and the gameplay is there just so he can sold it as game. At some point of the game I was making deliveries just because I wanted to move in the sotry. No building, no unnecesary deliveries, just interested to move in the story because that was what kept me playing.
I'm not saying the game is perfect, I actually agree with some of your points, for example the chiral artist voice acting was really funny cringe but you must realize that your opinions are just that. Opinions. Sometimes people are right when they say that you just didn't get it. Because you objectively didn't get the story. You admitted it yourself. And instead of you saying "I think it's nonsensical" or "I didn't get it" you straight up said it's nonsensical and weak part of the game. If you think it's the weak part of the game, ok that's your opinion, but saying it's nonsensical is objectively wrong, you really just didn't get it. If you at least got it, then you can say you think it's bad. But if you didn't get it, your opinion about the story is irrelevant.
Also this is first Kojima game I have ever played, so I'm definitely not his fanboy. I just don't mind stories that are hard to follow and everything fits together at the end.

Author: @thefakejoel7323
Comment:
I've been playing games since I was little, like 4 years old when i first got pokemon platinum for the ds that my sister gave me. I've played probably most titles you can think of, and even more that you don't think of, and I have to say, death stranding is oen of my favorite games of all time, just behind minecraft (nothing will ever replace minecraft no matter how good though because it was a giant part of my childhood and is how i know all my friends).

Death stranding is one of, if not the most unique game i have ever played. I first played it back on release for the ps4, dont even know why i bought it if I'm being honest cause at the time i was busy playing like rdr2, god of war, and monster hunter. But to this day, death stranding remains my favorite out of all of those and many others, i fell so in love with it that i beat it on ps4, it released on pc and i beat it again, and then the directors cut released and i beat it one more time and even 100%-ed it. i have nothing else to do in the game because i've done everything and i've since deleted it on my pc, but i keep getting that itch to go back and play it. Luckily the sequel should be coming out this year, and im ngl i cried when they first announced it cause i never thought theyd make a second one, but man im so excited to see what other kind of wacky things they did with the characters and story and gameplay.

Author: @alexsensei_hi
Comment:
Story time: 
My wife and I were walking around the Tokyo area and we stopped by Shinagawa, where the Shinkansen stops. Before going to see my grandma, we decided to check out the local area. We found a cool park and walked around. Was a really good time. Eventually, we got hungry. So, while walking around to find a restaurant that looked good, we decided to check out the restaurants in the building his office is located. 

As we entered, I saw the statue for his company and had no idea what it was at first. I just thought it was cool. I approached the statue and noticed a sign saying Kojima Productions and was like "HOLY SHIT", IS HIS OFFICE HERE? I am a long-time Metal Gear fan and loved the concept for Death Stranding as it was being unveiled. I hadn't played it at the time we visited, so I didn't know of the new mascot, but now that I'm finally playing the game (chapter 6 now) this video gets recommended to me. 

Life is pretty interesting, I must say. Love it!

Author: @mishukzoo
Comment:
Playing this game during the pandemic really hit a note. The whole asynchronous cross-play is such a great idea that I hope to one day see it implemented in other games as well. 

All the haters of this game have clearly not played more than a couple of  hours into the story. Once the game opens up it just keeps evolving. There is a point when you reach about 80% through the story and you think to yourself "This is probably it. There's no more new mechanics" . And then the game just keeps giving you more upgrades and expanding the playing field even more. It's a masterpiece in storytelling and game design that I will never forget!

Author: @NEUR0MANCER_
Comment:
Yea death stranding is pretentious garbage. Like a nicolas winding refn movie that has no guard rails. The difference between drive, and too old to die young. One is engineered to appeal to a specific kind of audience member, and too old to die young is for that audience member, but to ruin their day, And thats because nwr tries to move further and further from what makes a great narrative, leaning into lame ass shit. That appeals to a very niche of a niche audience. I hate the ending of too old to die young. Its like the antithesis to drives ending. And thats what kojima did with death stranding, he tried to hard to redefine what a game is, and only succeeded in making something that didnt just have a lame story but lakme mediocre gameplay. Would of been better if it was a game that had a more interesting concept, with maybe a defense based hand to hand combat system.

Expanding on what was only glimpsed in metal gear with one button.

If he wanted to redefine games, he should of went with the logical alternative to guns, hand to hand. Would of made it way more interesting and unique. People make walking and exploration simulators. But do in ways that focus on combat first. which is why you actually play the game.

But we have never really seen many hand to hand games with large exploratio. Only batman arkham. which has alot of potential to bleed into other games.

But no one is doing it. Usually you have a gun or a sword. its very rare that a game allows you to just pull off cool and dynamic hand to hand combat scenarios, that arent just a hack and slash with fists. but an active defense based combat engine, that focuses on more realistic aspects of fighting, like blocking and countering.

I slept on this game, it did not intrigue me and I really had no interest in the story. It came into the playstation catalogue recently and I decided to download cuz I was pretty much caught up with the rest of my gaming.
 I'm now 40+ hrs in and I'm still going. Jesus christ I did not realize how satisfying this game is. A simple concept of making a delivery,  turns into me spending time managing my inventory,  caring for container condition, plotting routes that avoid rain, getting the most orders completed during that run. I dont know what it is but I'm really loving this game and mad at myself for waiting this long to play it.

3 years later this game is not talked about as a masterpiece, in fact its enlightening what actually was happening. Ppl romantized Kojima and his past success and when this came out it was looked at as an art piece instead of a fun videogame. Author: @Segundachanceemgames
Comment:
I think we all got a "wow that was awesome" moment in this game, the first time I was like "this is a different experience than anything I've ever played"
Was when I was doing a delivery, it was very heavy, bb was stressed, it was raining, I was close to lose the cargo due to the acid damage and out of nowhere, I've found a rain shelter, playing the most heart warming song... Another player put the shelter there, and it was such a great experience, just different from everything else, cause he literally helped me, In real life, he saved my time, and helped me with the stress I was under, trying hard to finish that deliver and thinking that everything was over, I would lose the cargo and all...
It's just something you have to experience yourself.
This is coming from a guy who loves from software games, looter shooters and all of those action games.
I love Death Stranding, and can't wait to play DS2‚ù§

Author: @BienerSchnitzelCheekoroni
Comment: This game is pretty mixed, some people enjoy the walking and some find it boring. But like or hate it, you can't deny Kojima is a genius, the creativity is unmatched. I bought this game when it first came out and i recently bought it on PC and im still memorized how some of the locations look so unique and amazing. The fun part isn't walking, the fun part is getting yourself in a scary scenario like being stuck in a BT area or trying to get off from a big mountain on your bike and getting out of it and delivering your order successfully. If you want a game that's unique and a completely different experience than any other game, then Death Stranding is the game you should choose.

Author: @Nicolas-yd2mw
Comment:
My problem with Kojima is how his stories can fall appart when he implements dumb stuff or revolting situations. Like in Metal gear the almost naked sniper girl and the shower scene or the TONS of stupid characters with X-men like powers... Seriously if art need some masturbation to make itself clear.... it's garbage. Because, basicaly, art is related to work and the amount of it invested in the piece of art. If Kojima doesn't work more on theses aspects this is not style...  this is lazyness.
Like plots you can't understand and someone says "it's the charm of it to not understand it !"... no it's a flaw and one of the many mistakes done by it's creator.
Kojima makes decent games, but the japanese foolishness can break things appart.

That's why i'm not that fond of him especially on the moral debate brought in almost all his games.
The only good one is in Metal Gear and about  being peverted by the thrill of the kill or at least fighting constent wars.
A very Rambo 1 theme wich is always refreshing (because most people nowadays just forget thzt comfort is precious and should be protected)... the rest about dumb eugenic stuff and reincarnation (oh god the plot with Liquid Snake is sooooo bad !) is terrible.

N.B : Kojima is a proof of how bad the mainstream culture is. Where super powers and wars makes average stakes in stories.

Comment:
No one is more wrong than the gamers who try to claim that "videogames need to be fun to be good". Let's forget about the fact that Death stranding IS fun, provided you have an attention span that is at least the length of that of an averagely intelligent human....

....imagine if i tried to say the same thing about movies: "movies need to be fun to watch,in order to be good." Author: @chanwooksook
Comment:
this is a genius game. peak kojima at this point. i love love an love every second of it. game mechanics (never boring, always consist of interesting cycles,), story (it blew me away and i was crying in the end with a smile on my face - such a beautiful ending), world (never felt empty or boring as some say - the feeling of a melancholy and postapocalypsys should be like this), art direction and design (for sci fi fan - this is one of the best stuff i have ever witnessed in any media...its like kubrick, lynch, nolan, blocamp movies), drama and melodrama, music, humour (kojima style), references to pop culture personalities (cooles  casting ever for movie/gaming fans)...i have never been so carried away in game ever. finished story, while crafting world and doing most side missions in 88 hours in 8 days straight, played 11 hours each day (or night).

10/10. one of the best games of the generation and maybe my new favorite game ever. should have won every game award.

p.s. it's so cool to discover that second part is in development. most anticipated game for me now. 
am now reading kojimas book and discovering some cool books that inspired kojima's imagination.

Author: @sanda386
Comment:
Hey, pedantic history buff here I guess. The big five extinction events have actually happened, and so far the most recent one was the one that wiped out the dinosaurs, so no wooly mammoths, which were way more recent and in fact co-existed with our direct ancestors. The game mythology posits the hypothesis that these actual historical extinctions were caused by Death Stranding/Extinction Entities events, instead of the more "natural causes" that are usually thought to have been the culprits.

Thanks for ordering the in-game events for me tho, I just finished it and had some gaps ends in my mental interpretation of the events.

Comment: Thank you for the explanation. While watching a walkthrough of this game (I don't own modern console or PC to play it by myself) I too was very intrigued by the story. I thought to myself... OMG, this is brilliant. But after finishing I thought about some questions: 1. Amelie is said to be EE, which is something objective (this is her fate). But without saving Sam nothing would have happened. So basically everyone can be an EE - this isn't a fate but just an effect of decisions made by this character, 2. If a person consists of Ka and Ha, why Sam, Higgs, Die-hardman etc. didn't meet their "clones" after visiting the beach? 3. Why Amelie is not a BT? She just travels from the beach to talk with Sam. 4. If BT's have an antimatter within, why people's Ha can travel to the beach without cousing any consequences? 5. How is that possible that Ka and Ha are separate? See Amelie. And how is Ka connected with death - this is a soul of a living organism. And how curing someone on the beach can affect Ha, if Ha is separate from Ka? And how Deathman is alive if he doesn't have Ka at all??? At least for me, the plot is messed up pretty good and many things don't add up.

Author: @mushroom_dinosaur
Comment:
I know this is a e year old video but I really need to get this off my chest.
Death Stranding is my favourite game. Truly, it is, but as a paleontologist I do have ONE problem with the game:
The featured EEs of a Mammoth and a Human before [redacted] DO NOT fit the model of the big 5 mass extinctions. The most recent is the extinction of the dinosaurs.
That said, I can forgive it if Kojima is also including minor extinction events, which are still mass extinctions, just not the Big 5. In that case, the mammoth and the human would actually fit, considering mammoths did go extinct with a bunch of other Ice Age megafauna, and we are the only species of human left out of who knows how many, AND we went through a population bottleneck that nearly drove us to extinction. 
But yeah, definitely my favourite game. ‚ù§

Author: @RickClark58
Comment: I know this is an old vid but I am going to comment anyway. I dislike this story and personally don't feel it is executed well. It is a horror story masquareding as a sci-fi story and while trying to straddle the two genre, it services both genres poorly. This in my mind is a horror story. You don't need all the silly explanations as to why this event is happening, nor do you need the silly repeating extinction motif presented in the game. Horror is much more effective if you don't explain. You could leave the gameplay mechanics in place and make the story about an event that has mysterious and unknown origins. This game could have been an extremely interesting cosmic horror game but instead it is a silly story with a silly explanation that dilutes the horrific intent of the game.

Author: @jjdude00
Comment: There were not just 5 extinctions, and 5 EE's. There were a ton of smaller scale extinctions throughout all of prehistory, all with their own EE's. Neanderthals for example, did not exist anywhere near the latest of the Big 5, so a Neanderthal EE couldn't be responsible for one. Also Death Strandings are not the same as extinctions, though obviously they are connected. Amelie caused the Death Stranding by repatriating Sam, causing a breach between life and death. There are evidences of previous Death Strandings though, like the caveman BT drawings and tar samples found in earth's crust. So Death Strandings are possible side effects of the EE's, but did not necessarily happen in every extinction.

Author: @NoraNoita
Comment:
Before watching and after seeing the intro saying it takes 10 hours for it to become a good story, honestly,  the gameplay loop for me is not even interesting enough, you're a Post-carrier, and errand missions are plently in MMOs already, and they most likely will feature better NPC stories than the majority of errands you run in this game,
I spent hours of grinding in JRPG games, because albeit mind numbing and you doing the same thing over and over again just to see a number max out, it still is a satisfying experience for me.
I will see how this video unfolds, and will post an edit before posting this comment or an addendum with my opinion of the game afterwards.
Addendum: 11:00 that's not how scars work, especially when aging up.
overall, meh, never played Metal Gear Solid, so not really familiar with Kojima's work, but not really a fan of the ending, the middle bit characters seem interesting and the story up until it's apex looks interesting as a concept as well, but nothing more than the concept of it is interesting, the post climax is lackluster and doesn't keep my interest overall.

Great video though, I think I understand the basic gist of it all now.
